db:abstract.db:para: The QSet::const_iterator class provides an STL-style const iterator for QSet.

db:section.db:title: Detailed Description
db:section.db:para: QSet features both STL-style iterators and Java-style iterators. The STL-style iterators are more low-level and more cumbersome to use; on the other hand, they are slightly faster and, for developers who already know STL, have the advantage of familiarity.

QSet<Key, T>::const_iterator allows you to iterate over a QSet. If you want to modify the QSet as you iterate over it, you must use QSet::iterator instead. It is generally good practice to use QSet::const_iterator on a non-const QSet as well, unless you need to change the QSet through the iterator. Const iterators are slightly faster, and can improve code readability.

The default QSet::const_iterator constructor creates an uninitialized iterator. You must initialize it using a function like QSet::begin(), QSet::end(), or QSet::insert() before you can start iterating. Here's a typical loop that prints all the items stored in a set:
STL-style iterators can be used as arguments to generic algorithms. For example, here's how to find an item in the set using the qFind() algorithm:

db:warning.db:para: Iterators on implicitly shared containers do not work exactly like STL-iterators. You should avoid copying a container while iterators are active on that container. For more information, read Implicit sharing iterator problem.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator::iterator_category
db:section.db:para: Synonyms for std::bidirectional_iterator_tag indicating these iterators are bidirectional iterators.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator::const_iterator()
db:section.db:para: Functions like operator*() and operator++() should not be called on an uninitialized iterator. Use operator=() to assign a value to it before using it.

db:section.db:title: const T &const_iterator::operator*() const
db:section.db:para: Returns a reference to the current item.

db:section.db:title: const T *const_iterator::operator->() const
db:section.db:para: Returns a pointer to the current item.

db:section.db:title: bool const_iterator::operator==(const const_iterator &other) const
db:section.db:para: Returns true if other points to the same item as this iterator; otherwise returns false.

db:section.db:title: bool const_iterator::operator!=(const const_iterator &other) const
db:section.db:para: Returns true if other points to a different item than this iterator; otherwise returns false.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator &const_iterator::operator++()
db:section.db:para: The prefix ++ operator (++it) advances the iterator to the next item in the set and returns an iterator to the new current item.
Calling this function on QSet<T>::constEnd() leads to undefined results.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator const_iterator::operator++(int)
db:section.db:para: The postfix ++ operator (it++) advances the iterator to the next item in the set and returns an iterator to the previously current item.
